Detailed Description

The functions described in this group are declared in the gt_base.h header file and implemented in the libgtbase library. For more implementation and usage details, see the notes for the header file.

Define Documentation

#define GT_VERSION   (0 << 24 | 3 << 16 | 8)

Version number of the API, as a 4-byte integer, with the major number in the highest, minor number in the second highest and build number in the two lowest bytes. The preprocessor macro is included to enable conditional compilation.

See also:
GT_getVersion

Typedef Documentation

typedef int64_t GT_Int64

Generic 64-bit signed integer.

typedef GT_Int64 GT_Time_t64

This type is used as a 64-bit time_t.

Note:
Your system's standard time_t may be 32- or 64-bit, depending on the operating system, compiler, and in some cases even on the compiler settings.
Even when the value contained in a GT_Time_t64 variable is within the range of time_t, care must be taken to avoid using localtime(), gmtime(), etc in multithreaded programs, as these functions may rely on internal static buffers shared among all threads in an application.
typedef uint64_t GT_UInt64

Generic 64-bit unsigned integer.

typedef struct GTMessageDigest_st GTDataHash

A GuardTime hash sum object, used as the seed to create a GTTimestamp and again when verifying that timestamp to create a GTVerificationInfo.

When calculating the hash sum of some data to verify a timestamp, make sure to use the same hash algorithm as when the timestamp was created.

Enumeration Type Documentation

enum GTHashAlgorithm

The GuardTime representation of hash algorithms, necessary to calculate instances of GTDataHash.

The currently supported algorithms are:

NameOIDGT IDdigest size (bytes)
SHA11.3.14.3.2.26020
SHA2242.16.840.1.101.3.4.2.4328
SHA2562.16.840.1.101.3.4.2.1132
SHA3842.16.840.1.101.3.4.2.2448
SHA5122.16.840.1.101.3.4.2.3564
RIPEMD1601.3.36.3.2.1220

Names are as in the ASN.1 OID registry as defined in ITU-T Rec. X.660 / ISO/IEC 9834 series.

Enumerator:
GT_HASHALG_SHA1 

The SHA-1 algorithm.

GT_HASHALG_SHA256 

The SHA-256 algorithm.

GT_HASHALG_RIPEMD160 

The RIPEMD-160 algorithm.

GT_HASHALG_SHA224 

The SHA-224 algorithm.

GT_HASHALG_SHA384 

The SHA-384 algorithm.

GT_HASHALG_SHA512 

The SHA-512 algorithm.

GT_HASHALG_DEFAULT 

Use default algorithm.

enum GTStatusCode

GuardTime status codes.

Enumerator:
GTBASE_LOWEST 

The lowest result code of the range reserved for the base module. See GTStatusCode for definition of codes within this range.

GTBASE_HIGHEST 

The highest result code of the range reserved for the base module. See GTStatusCode for definition of codes within this range.

GTHTTP_LOWEST 

The lowest result code of the range reserved for the HTTP transport. See GTHTTPStatusCode for definition of codes within this range. Note, however, that the HTTP functions can also relay errors from the base module.

GTHTTP_HIGHEST 

The highest result code of the range reserved for the HTTP transport. See GTHTTPStatusCode for definition of codes within this range.

GTPNG_LOWEST 

The lowest result code of the range reserved for the PNG integration. See GTPNGStatusCode for definition of codes within this range. Note, however, that the PNG functions can also relay errors from the base module and HTTP transport.

GTPNG_HIGHEST 

The highest result code of the range reserved for the PNG integration. See GTPNGStatusCode for definition of codes within this range.

GT_OK 

The operation completed successfully.

GT_EARLIER 

When comparing timestamps, one timestamp was found to be earlier than another.

GT_NOT_EARLIER 

It could not be determined, whether one timestamp is earlier than another.

GT_EXTENDED 

A timestamp was found to be extended.

GT_NOT_EXTENDED 

A timestamp was found to be not extended.

GT_INVALID_ARGUMENT 

Argument to function was invalid. Mostly this indicates NULL pointer.

GT_INVALID_FORMAT 

Either arguments to function or responses from timestamping server had invalid format.

GT_UNTRUSTED_HASH_ALGORITHM 

Timestamp contained hash algorithm that is considered untrustworthy by the verification policy.

GT_UNTRUSTED_SIGNATURE_ALGORITHM 

Timestamp contained signature algorithm that is considered untrustworthy by the verification policy.

GT_INVALID_LINKING_INFO 

Hash chain containing linking info is missing or invalid.

GT_UNSUPPORTED_FORMAT 

Unsupported data format (that is, data has valid format but unsupported version or contains an unrecognized critical extension).

GT_DIFFERENT_HASH_ALGORITHMS 

Compared hashes are created using different hash algorithms.

GT_PKI_BAD_ALG 

Unrecognized or unsupported hash algorithm.

GT_PKI_BAD_REQUEST 

Bad request.

GT_PKI_BAD_DATA_FORMAT 

Bad data format.

GT_PROTOCOL_MISMATCH 

Unsupported extension(s) found in request.

GT_NONSTD_EXTEND_LATER 

Try to extend later. Non-standard error code from extender server.

GT_NONSTD_EXTENSION_OVERDUE 

Timestamp cannot be extended anymore. Non-standard error code from extender server.

GT_UNACCEPTED_POLICY 

Unaccepted policy.

GT_WRONG_DOCUMENT 

The digest contained in the stamp does not match the document.

GT_WRONG_SIZE_OF_HISTORY 

The number of history imprints was wrong.

GT_REQUEST_TIME_MISMATCH 

The hash chains for request and time have different shapes.

GT_INVALID_LENGTH_BYTES 

Level restriction bytes in the location hash chain steps are not strictly increasing. See the timestamp format specification for more details.

GT_INVALID_AGGREGATION 

The application of the hash chain containing aggregation data does not give the expected result. A possible cause for this error is that data submitted to verification process is not the same data used for timestamping.

GT_INVALID_SIGNATURE 

Signature value in timestamp is invalid.

GT_WRONG_SIGNED_DATA 

The value of the MessageDigest signed attribute is not equal to the digest of the TSTInfo structure.

GT_TRUST_POINT_NOT_FOUND 

Could not find published data or trusted TSA certificate for verifying the timestamp.

GT_INVALID_TRUST_POINT 

Published data with the given ID has different digest(s).

GT_CANNOT_EXTEND 

Timestamp cannot be extended because the extension response contains data items presumably from the past that are not part of the short-term stamp.

GT_ALREADY_EXTENDED 

Timestamp is already extended.

GT_KEY_NOT_PUBLISHED 

The signing key is not found among published ones.

GT_CERT_TICKET_TOO_OLD 

The signing key seems to have been used before it was published.

GT_OUT_OF_MEMORY 

The operation couldn't be performed because of lack of memory.

GT_IO_ERROR 

I/O error, check errno for more details. But check it soon, before someone resets it.

GT_TIME_OVERFLOW 

A time value is outside the range of time_t.

GT_CRYPTO_FAILURE 

Cryptographic operation could not be performed. Likely causes are unsupported cryptographic algorithms, invalid keys and lack of resources.

GT_PKI_SYSTEM_FAILURE 

Internal error.

GT_UNKNOWN_ERROR 

Unexpected error condition.

Function Documentation

void* GT_calloc ( size_t  n,
size_t  s 
)

Tries to allocate memory from GuardTime library's heap. This function present mainly for the benefit of other modules of the GuardTime SDK.

Parameters:
n(in) - The requested number of items to allocate.
s(in) - The size of each item.
Returns:
pointer to the allocated block, or NULL.
Note:
In certain configurations (most notably when using DLLs in Windows) different parts of a program may be using different memory heaps. Therefore, always release memory allocated by GT_calloc() with GT_free().
void GT_finalize ( void   )

Frees resources used by timestamping library. Must be called once after any other API functions. No GuardTime API functions can be used after this function is called.

void GT_free ( void *  p )

Frees memory (character strings, byte arrays, etc) that was allocated by the GuardTime library and returned to the user. It is safe to pass null pointer to this function.

Since all GuardTime functions leave (out) and (in/out) parameters intact on any errors, the following idiom could be used to ensure memory clean-up in all cases: 

    void *p = NULL;
    ...
    if (GT_function(&p) == GT_OK) {
       ...
       use *p here
       ...
    }
    ...
    GT_free(p);

Alternatively, if you want to bail out immediately on any errors to avoid deep nesting of if statements, you could use: 

    void *p = NULL;
    ...
    if (GT_function(&p) != GT_OK) {
       goto cleanup;
    }
    ...
    use *p here
    ...
 cleanup:
    ...
    GT_free(p);
Parameters:
p(in) - Pointer that is to be freed.
Note:
In certain configurations (most notably when using DLLs in Windows) different parts of a program may be using different memory heaps. Therefore, only use GT_free() to relase memory allocated with GT_malloc(), GT_calloc(), and GT_realloc(), or returned to you from a GuardTime SDK function.
const char* GT_getErrorString ( int  error )

Gets human readable error string in English.

Parameters:
error(in) - GuardTime status code.
Returns:
error string (it is static, don't try to free it).
Note:
This function only knows about the status codes defined in the base module of the SDK. For descriptions of codes defined in other modules, see the getErrorString() methods in the respective modules.
int GT_getVersion ( void   )

Returns the version number of the library.

Returns:
version number of the API, as a 4-byte integer, with the major number in the highest, minor number in the second highest and build number in the two lowest bytes.
See also:
GT_VERSION
int GT_hashFile ( const char *  path,
int  hash_algorithm,
GTDataHash **  data_hash 
)

Hashes contents of the given file.

Parameters:
path(in) Name of the file to read.
hash_algorithm(in) - Identifier of the hash algorithm. See GTHashAlgorithm for possible values.
data_hash(out) - Pointer that will receive pointer to the hashed data.
Returns:
GT_OK on success, otherwise an error code; use errno to get more specific reason when GT_IO_ERROR is returned.
int GT_init ( void   )

Initializes timestamping library. Must be called once before any other API functions.

Returns:
status code (GT_OK, when operation succeeded, otherwise an error code).
int GT_loadFile ( const char *  path,
unsigned char **  out_data,
size_t *  out_size 
)

Reads contents of the given file into memory.

Parameters:
path(in) Name of the file to read.
out_data(out) Pointer to the variable that receives pointer to the output data on success. This data must be freed with GT_free() when not needed anymore.
out_size(out) Pointer to the variable that receives length of the output data on success.
Returns:
GT_OK on success, otherwise an error code; use errno to get more specific reason when GT_IO_ERROR is returned.
Note:
For convenience of handling in case of text files, a zero byte is always appended to the loaded data. But the size returned in out_size is still the actual size of the file without the extra byte.
void* GT_malloc ( size_t  s )

Tries to allocate memory from GuardTime library's heap. This function present mainly for the benefit of other modules of the GuardTime SDK.

Parameters:
s(in) - The requested size of the block to allocate.
Returns:
pointer to the allocated block, or NULL.
Note:
In certain configurations (most notably when using DLLs in Windows) different parts of a program may be using different memory heaps. Therefore, always release memory allocated by GT_malloc() with GT_free().
void* GT_realloc ( void *  p,
size_t  s 
)

Tries to extend a memory block allocated from GuardTime library's heap. This function present mainly for the benefit of other modules of the GuardTime SDK.

Parameters:
p(in) - Pointer to the original memory block.
s(in) - The requested new size of the block.
Returns:
pointer to the allocated block, or NULL.
Note:
In certain configurations (most notably when using DLLs in Windows) different parts of a program may be using different memory heaps. Therefore, always release memory allocated by GT_realloc() with GT_free().
int GT_saveFile ( const char *  path,
const void *  in_data,
size_t  in_size 
)

Saves the given contents into file.

Parameters:
path(in) Name of the file to save.
in_data(in) Pointer to the data to be saved.
in_size(in) Size of the data to be saved.
Returns:
GT_OK on success, otherwise an error code; use errno to get more specific reason when GT_IO_ERROR is returned.

const unsigned char *  data,
size_t  data_length,
GTDataHash **  data_hash

See also:

data(in) - Pointer to the data to be hashed.
data_length(in) - Length of the hashed data.
data_hash(out) - Pointer that will receive pointer to the hashed data.

const char* GTHash_oid ( int  hash_algorithm )

Returns the ASN.1 OID for the given hash algorithm, in the dotted decimal format. See GTHashAlgorithm for list of supported algorithms and their OID's.

Parameters:
hash_algorithm(in) - The hash algorithm whose OID is requested.
Returns:
pointer to a static string (no need to free it), or NULL if the input value does not represent a supported hash algorithm.
